newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends sharply down on LME losses.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends sharply down on LME losses.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended sharply down with later-maturing contracts hitting a 1996 low on Monday due to last Friday's losses on the London Metal Exchange, traders said.
The most active January 1997 contract ended at 19,420 yuan ($2,340) per tonne, losing 240 yuan. It opened at an intra-day high of 19,600 and hit a low of 19,350.
October fell 280 to 19,320 yuan, November 300 to 19,300, December 270 to 19,350, February 210 to 19,450, March 150 to 19,500 and April 250 to 19,550.
Combined volume rose to 73,890 tonnes from 63,900.
Copper opened lower and fell further for most of the session with the most active January and February contracts breaching the key 19,500 support level.
Traders said speculative and hedging selling emerged at high levels due to last Friday's LME losses and over-surplus of domestic spot copper.
"The poor market sentiment did not change and many investors built short positions at high levels today," one trader said.
"Copper is likely to find further support at low levels in the short term," he added.
Traders said futures prices faced heavy pressure with domestic spot price dropping step by step.

"Falls of spot prices indicated domestic spot demand has not improved at all despite a booming consumer season," a second trader said. Prices of spot copper in Shanghai has fallen to about 20,000 yuan per tonne from 20,100 two weeks ago.
Traders expect copper to test the 19,000 yuan key support level in the next few days on weak market sentiment.
Aluminium ended down. October fell 120 to 13,580, November 40 to 13,600, December 150 to 13,400 and January 200 to 13,300.
Combined volume rose to 1,410 tonnes from 800.
